University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 21 to 35. EU Horizon 2020 is coming; EU Funding and learning from colleagues\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experiences https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/december/eu-horizon-2020-is-coming-eu-funding-and-learning-from-colleagues2019-experiences Frank and Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome Building - 11 Dec 2013, 03:00PM - 05:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Biology Chemistry Event:Lecture Physics 2013-12-11T15:00:00Z UoL Event International Space Station turns 15 https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/international-space-station-turns-15 To mark the 15th anniversary of the International Space Station, we look back on a selection of 15 achievements in our space research The University has been a world-leader in space science for more than half a century,\ufffd\ufffdthanks to\ufffd\ufffdour award-winning Department of Physics and Astronomy. To celebrate the 15th birthday of the International Space Station, the largest artificial body in orbit, first launched on 20 November 1998, here are 15 of our space achievements:

  1. Every year since 1967, there has been a University of Leicester-built instrument operating in space
  2. In 1975 we identified the existence of black holes previously predicted by Einstein
  3. A new solar system was discovered with the help of our intellectual property
  4. We were a founding partner of the National Space Centre which opened in 2001 as the UK's only attraction dedicated to space science
  5. Honorary graduate and visiting Professor, astronaut Jeff Hoffman officially opened our observatory in 2009 for staff and students
  6. The Space Research Centre is exploring the use of Britain's nuclear waste to power spacecraft
  7. Our aerospace engineers are quite literally taking off with a new practical module\ufffd\ufffd
  8. What does space sound like? Andrew Williams, Leverhulme Artist in Residence at the Space Research Centre reveals all
  9. Our scientists created the most extensive cosmic X-ray catalogue in existence, which is home to some of the Universe's rarest phenomena
  10. Dr John Bridges was involved in the discovery of clay samples containing key ingredients for ancient life on Mars
  11. Professor George Fraser is Principal Investigator on one of the main instruments that will fly on the Bepi Colombo mission to Mercury
  12. Canada's first astronaut Chris Hadfield will be visiting the University on Friday 13 December to share how he 'thinks like an astronaut'
  13. Evidence for a new kind of cosmic explosion - a kilonova - was found by our space scientists
  14. In 2010, our first space scientist, Professor Ken Pounds celebrated his golden anniversary and 50 years of space science at Leicester
  15. In 2011, four of our Physics and Astronomy students experienced weightlessness in a gravity-defying European Space Agency experiment

\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher ap507 Physics and Astronomy Space Projects and Instrumentation Space missions Space Instrumentation Space-borne Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff Magazine:Business Space Space Projects Physics Magazine:Student Space Research Centre 2013-11-21T09:37:59Z Blog Entry Is our society a quantum world? University academic's research featured in New Scientist https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/august/is-our-society-a-quantum-world-university-academic-featured-in-new-scientist School of Management Professor\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds collaborative book applies quantum mechanics to social systems The work of a Leicester academic on linking quantum physics and social sciences\ufffd\ufffdhas been featured in the New Scientist.

When it comes to looking at how our minds work, you might not think physicists up to the job: after all, how does the study of atoms, electrons and radiation relate to the realm of senses, emotions, consciousness and unconsciousness? But Emmanuel Haven, Professor in the School of Management, argues that the rules of the quantum world can help us make sense of complex social systems, in collaboration with Professor Andrei Khrennikov of Linnaeus University in Sweden.

Professors Haven and Khrennikov propose that we apply \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdquantum-like\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd models to areas outside of the natural remit of quantum physics, such as social sciences. They argue that classical laws of probability often cannot apply to complex real-life situations, which are influenced by a blend of social, physical and financial factors. Quantum mechanics shows that in many cases, particles behave in relation to other particles: either through \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdentanglement\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (particles behaving as a unit even if they are far apart) or through \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcomplementarity\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (the idea that it is impossible to distinguish between the behaviour of an atomic object and its interaction with the instrument observing it). The problem with classical probability laws is that they cannot accommodate context as quantum probability can.

Haven and Khrennikov also hope to apply their research to understanding brain science, noting that quantum science has already kick-started the field of quantum-like artificial intelligence explored by Google and NASA. They are also looking at how voters are influenced by a stream of mass-media information: the so-called quantum master equation allows them to describe interactions between a social system and its environment, and thus the dynamics of voter\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds preferences.

Quantum social science is still a young field, but\ufffd\ufffd scientists have been discussing the link between quantum physics and the human brain for some time: Wolfgang Pauli, winner of the 1945 Nobel Prize in Physics, proposed that the interaction between consciousness and unconsciousness could be understood in relation to complementarity.\ufffd\ufffd Similarly, over the past 15 years, there has been growing evidence that quantum mechanical processes can be applied to studying our sense of smell: it was proposed that a quantum mechanism is involved when odour molecules activate receptors in the nose.

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Physics Magazine:Student Research Management Magazine:Staff 2013-08-06T13:45:00Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt pull that!\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd University of Leicester physics students investigate Bond ejector seat https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/201cdon2019t-pull-that-201d-university-of-leicester-physics-students-investigate-bond-ejector-seat Four-year Master of Physics students examine famous seat from Goldfinger Master\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds students at the University of Leicester's Department of Physics and Astronomy have explored the feasibility of James Bond\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds DB5 ejector seat from Goldfinger: That is, the one Bond uses to get rid of unwanted passengers. Could this ever be a real feature of modern cars - as an optional extra, of course?

To find out, the team first studied the trajectory of the ejected\ufffd\ufffdhenchman in the film footage. They worked out the highest point the henchmen reached when ejected from the seat by measuring the pixels in the screenshots and comparing against the known height of the car. Using the maximum height of 2.37 m the team then modelled the motion of the ejected henchman.\ufffd\ufffd For all of you budding (or actual) secret agents out there, all you need to eject your typical henchman through the sunroof of an Aston Martin DB5 is a force of 1930 N and 8870 Pa respectively, exerted as a constant force via a hydraulic piston

Their paper, No Mr Bond, I Expect You To Drive, was published in the latest volume of the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics. The journal is published every year, and features original short papers written by students as part of their four-year Master of Physics degree \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and encourages students to think creatively, adopting off-the-wall topics. Still, no Aston Martin \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVanish\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd just yet \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the team found an invisible car was, sadly, not yet a possibility.

  • Read the press release
]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Student Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Physics 2013-07-03T10:25:39Z Blog Entry Space scholarship for Leicester alumnus https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/june/space-scholarship-for-leicester-alumnus-1 Former Physics and Astronomy student receives unique opportunity at the International Space University Ryan Laird, a graduate of the University of Leicester Department of Physics and Astronomy, has been awarded a 16,500 Euro scholarship by the UK Space Agency and European Space Agency (ESA) to join the Space Studies Programme (SSP) at the International Space University (ISU).

The Space Studies Programme is an intensive nine weeks of training, taking place around the world in a different location every year. Ryan will be travelling to France for the SSP\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds location this year: ISU's central campus in Strasbourg, with an opening reception at the European Parliament.

SSP gives the students the chance to develop contacts, as major figures from industry and government space agencies support the course.

In the same year Ryan graduated from the Department of Physics and Astronomy, he was chosen as the UK Student Representative for the International Year of Astronomy 2009. He now undertakes a voluntary role as the UK National Point of Contact for the Space Generation Advisory Council and most recently worked as their winter intern at their HQ at the European Space Policy Institute (ESPI) in Vienna, Austria, where he attended subcommittee meetings of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (UN COPUOS).

He is a STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) ambassador and science communicator working with science students to inspire them to reach for the stars. He runs a blog at\ufffd\ufffdrjmlaird.co.uk and Twitter stream\ufffd\ufffd@rjmlaird.

]]> No publisher pt91 Alumni Magazine:Student Physics Magazine:Staff 2013-06-21T13:40:00Z Blog Entry Do aliens use Sat Nav? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/april/needs-titled University of Leicester academic appears in a two-part documentary made for the Science Discovery Channel Dr John Pye, the Space Research Centre Manager from the Department of Physics and Astronomy has appeared in a new two-part documentary made for the Science Discovery Channel.

The documentary \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAliens the Definitive Guide\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd aired in the USA and Canada in March this year, and is an investigation into the latest scientific understanding of life beyond planet Earth.

Dr Pye's part in the documentary was to describe the methods by which Aliens might navigate in interstellar space; he talked about the use of X-ray pulsars for deep-space navigation \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd analogous to cosmic \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlighthouses\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or GPS. Filming included a half-day on the Solent \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd using the Needles and Hurst Castle lighthouses as analogies for X-ray pulsars!

The invitation to appear in the programme arose directly from work that a team involving members of the Department and partners at the National Physical Laboratory are undertaking for the European Space Agency, in a study contract on the use of X-ray pulsars for deep-space, interplanetary navigation.

]]> No publisher hct16 Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Physics 2013-04-23T14:30:00Z Blog Entry How much hot air is there in the House of Commons? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/march/hot-air-in-the-house-of-commons University of Leicester Physics students calculate that MPs debating in the Commons produce power equivalent to 1000 light bulbs

Cynical observers of UK politics might remark that MPs in the House of Commons produce a lot of useless hot air.

But according to University of Leicester physics students, the hot air produced by 650 MPs debating in the Commons actually releases up to 10.34 kilowatts of power which is the same as about 1000 energy saving light bulbs or 200 old fashioned light bulbs.

The group of fourth year MPhys students from the Department of Physics and Astronomy, published the findings in a paper entitled Hot Air in the House of Commons in this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics.

They calculated the power generated from heat flow as MPs breathe in air, heat the air to body temperature in their lungs before breathing out the air back into the room.

They also took into account the heat capacity and density of air as well as average volume flow rates and the power output created as water vapour from the exhaled breath condenses into liquid.

In a subsequent paper, Heat Loss in the House of Commons, the students added that new insulation installed as part of the general renovation of Westminster Palace could make the MPs heat output more useful - and reduce the energy bills of future Parliaments.

You can also listen to a podcast on this topic:

  • Press release
]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Physics Magazine:Student 2013-03-21T11:42:24Z Blog Entry Spider-Man Does Whatever a Spider Can: Spiderman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds webbing would be strong enough to stop a moving train. https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/february/spider-man-does-whatever-a-spider-can-spiderman2019s-webbing-would-be-strong-enough-to-stop-a-moving-train University of Leicester physics students calculate that the strength of Spiderman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds webbing is proportional to that of real spiders. In Spiderman 2, the superhero uses his webbing to bring a runaway train to a standstill moments before it plummets over the end of the track.

But could a material with the strength and toughness of spiders\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd web really stop four crowded subway cars?

According to University of Leicester physics students, the answer is yes.

The students found the force Spiderman's webs exert on the train to be 300,000 newtons.

They also found that the Young\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds modulus \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or stiffness \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of the web would be 3.12 gigapascals. This is very reasonable for spider's silk, which ranges from 1.5 gigapascals to 12 gigapascals in the orb-weaver spiders.

The toughness of the silk was calculated as almost 500 megajoules per cubic metre. This is in line with web from a Darwin's Bark Spider - an orb-weaver with the strongest known webbing of any spider.

They conclude that the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfriendly neighbourhood\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd superhero\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds webbing is indeed a proportional equivalent of that of a real spider \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and, consequently, it would be feasible for him to stop a moving train.

Alex Stone, 21, one of the students, said: It is often quoted that spider-webs are stronger than steel, so we thought it would be interesting to see whether this held true for Spiderman's scaled up version. Considering the subject matter we were surprised to find out that the webbing was portrayed accurately.

  • Press release

 

More information:
  • Their paper, Doing whatever a spider can, was published in the latest volume of the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Journal of Physics Special Topics.
  • The journal is published every year, and features original short papers written by students in the final year of their four-year Master of Physics degree.
  • The students are encouraged to be imaginative with their topics, and the aim is for them to learn about aspects of publishing and peer review.
]]> No publisher hct16 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Physics Magazine:Student 2013-02-25T10:35:00Z Blog Entry Reading the Red Planet https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/october/reading-the-red-planet All eyes are on Dr John Bridges \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the Leicester scientist analysing the Mars Curiosity Rover\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds findings. The successful landing of Nasa\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Curiosity Rover on Mars has been one of the biggest science stories of the year \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and University of Leicester planetary scientist Dr John Bridges has played a central role.

Dr Bridges, who is working at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California analysing data sent back from the rover, has been hitting the headlines, with a string of interviews and features on his work with the $2.5 billion project.

The Leicester Mercury reported that the rover has taken its first soil sample from the planet \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a key stage in the project\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds mission to ascertain whether the planet once supported life. The piece reveals that Dr Bridges has taken a leaf from English naturalist Charles Darwin\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds book Volcanic Islands to gain insight into Martian geology.

Last month, the Leicester Mercury published an in-depth feature on Dr Bridges' involvement, which details the kinds of discoveries the team are hoping to take from Curiosity\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds readings. Among the many things that Dr Bridges was looking forward to about the project was the chance to get a sense of what the Martian landscape really looks like.

Dr Bridges himself has been providing regular updates on the project on his own blog.

]]> No publisher hct16 Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Dr John Bridges Astronomy Physics Magazine:Student 2012-10-16T12:55:00Z Blog Entry The Dark Knight Rises - and crashes https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/july/the-dark-knight-rises-and-crashes Batman returns to cinemas for the Dark Knight Rises this month (July 20) - but unless he has invested in a new cape, he may fall into some trouble. Physics students have calculated that the superhero's method of using his cape to glide from tall buildings - as seen in Christopher Nolan's Batman Begins - would result in him hitting the ground at life-threateningly high speeds.

In the film, the caped crusader - played by Christian Bale - wears a cape which becomes rigid when a current is passed through it, allowing him to glide over Gotham City in a similar manner to a base jumper in a wingsuit.

Four MPhys students from the University of Leicester have published a paper claiming that although this method of gliding would be possible, Batman would be likely to suffer a fatal collision when he reached the ground.

Due to the high speeds he would be travelling, his impact with the ground would be equivalent to him being struck by a car travelling at 50 miles per hour.

David Marshall, Tom Hands, Ian Griffiths and Gareth Douglas found that the wingspan of Batman's cape - at 4.7 metres - is around half that used by a hang glider.

If Batman jumped from a building 150 metres high, he could glide a distance of around 350 metres - but the problem arises as Batman's velocity increases during his descent.

His velocity would initially rise to around 68 miles per hour, before reaching a steady 50 miles per hour as he gets down to ground level - a speed too fast for him to land safely.

The group concluded that DC Comics' superhero should consider taking a parachute with him if he wanted to stay in one piece.

David Marshall, 22, said: "If Batman wanted to survive the flight, he would definitely need a bigger cape. Or if he preferred to keep his style intact he could opt for using active propulsion, such as jets to keep himself aloft.

"If he really wanted to stick with tradition he could follow the method of Gary Connery, who recently became the first person to glide to the ground from a helicopter using only a wingsuit, although he only made it down safely using a large number of cardboard boxes."

The paper, entitled Trajectory of a falling Batman was published in this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds University of Leicester Journal of Special Physics Topics.

The journal is published every year, and features original short papers written by students in the final year of their four-year Master of Physics degree.

David added: "This was an enjoyable module to be involved with, but it was also a lot harder work than it sounds. Each fortnight we had to write our own papers, review the papers of other groups, make corrections to our reviewed papers and put together an editorial board meeting to discuss the outcomes for the papers currently in the process of review.

"Choosing creative projects did make the task a little easier and more interesting. I believe the module is worthwhile, as learning how to approach new problems is an important part of being a physicist."

Course leader Dr Mervyn Roy, a lecturer at the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Physics and Astronomy, said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA lot of the papers published in the Journal are on subjects that are amusing, topical, or a bit off-the-wall. Our fourth years are nothing if not creative! But, to be a research physicist - in industry or academia - you need to show some imagination, to think outside the box, and this is certainly something that the module allows our students to practice.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMost of our masters students hope to go on to careers in research where a lot of their time will be taken up with scientific publishing - writing and submitting papers, and writing and responding to referee reports.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThis is another area where the module really helps. Because Physics Special Topics is run exactly like a professional journal, the students get the chance to develop all the skills they will need when dealing with high profile journals like Nature or Science later on in life.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Physics Magazine:Student Film 2012-07-09T14:00:00Z Blog Entry Nanoscience in Istanbul https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/december/nanoparticles-in-istanbul Leicester establishing exchange link with leading nanotechnology centre. Chris Binns from our Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Research Group has recently returned from a trip to Turkey, laying the groundwork for a formal link between the University of Leicester and Fatih University.

Fatih is a relatively new university, established 15 years ago with 12,000 undergraduates \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd ten per cent of them from abroad \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd spread across two campuses in Ankara and Istanbul. What particularly attracted our CMP researchers was the university\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds multidisciplinary nanoscience centre which is planning to become a full-on nanotechnology institute with teaching and research programmes.

All lectures at Fatih are presented in duplicate: once in Turkish and again in English. Course work may also be submitted in either language so it is possible to study entirely in English, entirely in Turkish or, if you want to show off, in a mixture of both tongues.

Leicester students will be able to use the Erasmus European exchange programme to visit Fatih University and take advantage of the institution\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds cutting-edge nanotechnology labs as well as the other excellent campus facilities (not to mention the Istanbul nightlife!).

Our CMP group, which is part of our Department of Physics and Astronomy, conducts research into the relationship between atomic configurations, electronic structure and function with a particular interest in the structural and electronic properties of semiconductor nanostructures and the electronic properties of magnetic nanoparticles.

Inside the nanoscience centre at Fatih University
]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Condensed Matter Physics International Physics Magazine:Student 2011-12-22T12:55:00Z Blog Entry Public lecture on energy, environment and climate change https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/november/public-lecture-on-energy-environment-and-climate-change Former Chancellor considers conflicting needs of people and planet on 11 November. The former Chancellor of the University of Leicester, Sir Peter Williams CBE, FREng, FRS, returns to the campus on Friday 11 November 2011 to present a public lecture on: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdEnergy, Environment and Climate Change: Irreconcilable Conflict or Global Opportunity?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The tragic events earlier this year in Japan underlined the somewhat precarious balance between the needs of a growing global population for energy and the possibility of adverse consequences for the environment and humanity when this balance is disturbed, in this case by a natural disaster leading to technological failure.

The aftermath of events at Fukushima led, predictably, to calls for a curb on nuclear power generation, but this stance is at odds with the simultaneous drive for low carbon energy sources to combat the potential threats due to global warming. What do we know with certainty about such threats and how can we reconcile all these apparently conflicting pressures without a na\ufffd\ufffdve appeal to technologies which today do not even exist?

This talk will draw on recent Royal Society reports on topics as diverse as bio-fuels and geo-engineering and will also emphasise not only the scale of the challenge facing us, but the tremendous economic opportunities which could result from successful attempts to mitigate climate change. 

As well as his duties here, Sir Peter\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds current/former positions include Chairman of the National Physical Laboratory, Vice President and Treasurer of the Royal Society, President of the Institute of Physics, President of the British Association for the Advancement of Science and Chairman of the Engineering and Technology Board.

Jointly organised by our College of Science and Engineering and the Haldane Society, the lecture is free and open to all, with refreshments provided afterwards. It will take place in the Ken Edwards Building*, Lecture Theatre 1, starting at 6.30pm.

For more information please contact: Vicky Orson-Wright, vow@le.ac.uk, 0116 2522142 or Dr Emma Bunce, ejb10@ion.le.ac.uk, 0116 2523541

*NB. The lecture is being delivered by Peter Williams but is not in the Peter Williams Lecture Theatre.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Environment Magazine:Staff Physics Magazine:Student Public lecture 2011-11-03T17:32:38Z Blog Entry From truncheons to TASERs: public lecture on 'less lethal weapons' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/april/from-truncheons-to-tasers A free public lecture on Tuesday 12 April explores the science behind weapons that are designed to incapacitate but not kill. Around the world, police officers - even those who carry guns - generally try to avoid killing people wherever possible. So there is a surprisingly large global market for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdless lethal weapons\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd; that is, devices designed to restrain, scare away or cause temporary pain to wrongdoers.

The next public lecture from the Leicester Physics Centre is a fascinating talk by Dr David Wilkinson from the Institute of Physics on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Physics of Not Killing People\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. This is an area that Dr Wilkinson knows better than most folk because for several years he worked at the Home Office Scientific Development Branch*, the Government body responsible for testing and evaluating the wide range of non-lethal weapons produced by companies worldwide.

Less lethal weapons (there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a fairly obvious reason why the term \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnon-lethal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is generally avoided) include devices designed to restrain a person, which could be as simple as a net or as complex and impractical as a high-pressure jet of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsticky foam\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (great for stopping someone running away, less helpful afterwards when you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre trying to cuff them and get them into a van\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd).

Water cannons are a well-known less lethal weapon, designed to disperse crowds, but are rarely used in the UK. As Dr Wilkinson explains, this is a simple matter of urban geography: water cannons are actually very vulnerable vehicles which require a surrounding cordon of riot police, the water jet blasting above their heads. This is a practical proposition in big squares and plazas, but British rioters very inconsiderately tend to cause their civil unrest in relatively narrow streets.

Then there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds the TASER**, invented in 1974, which fires two wires at a miscreant and zaps him with electricity. The intention is to hurt him sufficiently that he falls over and is too bothered about the (temporary) pain to resist arrest. Dr Wilkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds illustrated lecture includes some memorable video footage of macho American cops testing TASERs on each other and finding out how much they really hurt.

Some of the photos in Dr Wilkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds lecture are a tad on the gruesome side so this event isn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt recommended for small children, but for everyone else it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds an utterly fascinating, very educational \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and in places quite entertaining - look into a largely undocumented field where science meets law enforcement.

The lecture, which is free and open to all, takes place in the Ken Edwards Building, Lecture Theatre 1, at 6.30pm on Tuesday 12 April 2011. Please use the online booking form to be sure of a seat,

  • Department of Physics and Astronomy
  • Lecture poster (PDF)

*Renamed last week as the Centre for Applied Science and Technology

**Incredibly, this stands for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThomas A Swift\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Electric Rifle\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. We are not making this up.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Physics Magazine:Student Public lecture 2011-04-08T10:50:42Z Blog Entry Is it magic? Is it science? Or a bit of both? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2010-archive/may-2010/is-it-magic-is-it-science-or-a-bit-of-both Arthur C Clarke once said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAny sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd A public lecture on 1 June will tread similar ground. Magician and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdself-confessed science fan\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Phill Smith will present The Physics of Magic, the Magic of Physics as the latest in a series of public lectures organised by the Leicester Physics Centre, part of our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

The first half of the talk will show how science is used as the basis for classic magic tricks, and the second half will demonstrate how current advances in physics are approaching what we might consider magic. Which brings us back to Clarke\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Law, above.

Smith has been performing magic professionally for a number of years as well as devising tricks for other performers and writing specialist books. He says:

Magic is the art of exploiting hidden knowledge to enact the impossible. Physics is the science of studying and quantifying the possible. A solid knowledge of physics can help with the mechanisms and hidden concepts that underpin much of magic.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The lecture is in the Bennett Building, Lecture Theatre 1, at 6.30pm on Tuesday 1 June. All are welcome.

  • University press release
]]> No publisher mjs76 Lecture Physics 2010-05-25T16:21:12Z Blog Entry Klaus von Haeften's Research Page https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/physics/research/cmp/academic-staff/kvh6/personal-research-page Since its first liquefaction almost hundred years ago helium has fascinated researchers because it shows macroscopic quantum effects in its condensed phases. Since I started research I have been interested in the properties of helium clusters and helium droplets - condensed phases that contain a few up to millions of helium atoms. One aspect of my research concerns electronically excited states. The helium atom is the simplest of all many-electron atoms. A fundamental questions that strikes me is how electronically excited states become modified when an excited helium atom is placed near one, two or more helium atoms in the ground state. I tackle this problem using molecular beams of clusters and droplets of helium which allow their size to be varied, and synchrotron radiation to produce electronic excitations. Helium clusters in molecular beams are always liquid allowing to probe disordered arrangements of helium atoms.

Another aspect of my research on helium is the interaction of molecules with helium. Rovibrational spectra show that molecules embedded in superfluid 4He droplets rotate as if they were free, however, their rotation is somewhat slower than in vacuum. This difference in rotational speed reflects the interaction with the helium environment. My interest is to investigate these sometimes very subtle interactions using new spectroscopic approaches that are currently under development in my group. With these new techniques we expect to be able to investigate, for instance, the effect of\ufffd\ufffd thermodynamic phase changes, the on-set of superfluidity and resonances with local and global excitations.

More recently, I have started investigating small clusters and nanoparticles of elements of technological relevance. In the focus are iron and silicon nanoparticles generated by using a range of innovative approaches developed in our group. We co-deposit silicon clusters with water vapour onto a cold target, melt the ice and obtain an aqueous suspension with exceptional optical stability: the clusters emit blue fluorescence in liquid water and show no signs of degrading. We also investigate the interaction with surfaces. AFM measurements of drops of silicon clusters placed on HOPG in ultra high vacuum show predominantly cluster heights of less than 1.5 nm and various forms of self-organisation.

Peer Reviewed Published Papers

Many of my papers can be found with Google and Google Scholar. Google also displays links to pdf files that are accessible through the Leicester Research Archive (LRA) at http://lra.le.ac.uk.

O. Vendrell, J. Kupper, M. Wolf, H. Chapman, M. Chergui, K. Reid, K. von Haeften, R.
Moshammer, G. Williams, A. Tehlar, G. Dixit, H. J. Worner, J. Underwood, J.Marangos,
M. Woerner, Ch. Bressler, M. Minitti, A. Kirrander, C. Vozzi and D. Rolles
